description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)

description: Israel's Ministry of Helath's Director General is signing the People's Health Ordinance that allows special education programs to open with a limit of up to 3 children per group, subject to maintaining a fifteen-minute buffer between groups and maintaining hygiene. description: On July 6 the Prime Minister’s Office and the Ministry of Health (Israel) announced restrictions following a sharp rise in COVID-19 infections. With regards to summer school, summer camps and youth activities - only kindergarten through fourth grade will be permitted. The government authorizes the Director General of the Ministry of Health to make a decision on educational activities for grades 5 and up in consultation with the Minister of Education.

institution_status: Secondary Schools closed/locked down

description: Israel is resuming all schools under the following restricitons: 2 meters between students, including during lunchtime, wearing masks, practicing hygiene.  The higher education resumes full operation according to the Ministry of Education guidelines: 2 meters between students, wearing masks, practicing hygiene. If an area is declared a red zones, schools will be closed in that zone.  Special education operate the same as the other schools, except nursing individuals: groups of 6.  The higher education system will hold online exams (except special cases).  High religious schools, religious schools (Midrasha) and Kolels will expand operation. Restrictions: No more than 50 participants, 2 meters distance between people (except physical activities), 2 meters distance can be kept on premise, and wearing masks.  Extracurricular programs, youth movements, and informal education:  Courses, ulpan, youth movement and informal education is permitted up to grade 4. Restrictions; up to 50 participants, maintaining a 2-meter person to person distance (except when carrying out activities that necessitate contact, such as sport activities), wearing masks, indoor activities – up to 50 people may participate, provided they maintain a distance of 2 meters, or alternately if they ensure that there will be no more than one person per 7 square meters, outdoor activities – up to 50 people may participate, while maintaining a distance of 2 meters.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class)

description:
Israel announced on August 10 that schools will open on September 1 for children in all grade levels, subject to restrictions. Those restrictions are:
- Preschool children will go to school 6 days a week with no restrictions
- Grades 1 and 2 will go to school 5 days a week with normal classroom sizes and will not be required to wear masks
- Grades 3 and 4 will go to school 5 days a week in classes no larger than 18 students, and will sit at individual tables. Grade 3 will be required to wear masks only at recess, and Grade 4 and above will wear masks all the time.
- Grades 5 and 6 will be at school 2 days a week, in classes no larger than 18 students, and will learn remotely at home the other 3 days.
- All students will be required to bring in a daily health form.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with no conditions

description: Israel is resuming educational activities for the 1st to 4th grades for at least 4 days a week, under regulations.  it was decided that the number of pupils will not exceed 20 pupils per class, except for the following exceptions: The Ministry of Education will create an exclusion organ that will allow up to 10% of all classes to learn in groups of up to 24 pupils, prioritizing educational establishments in areas with low infection rates. Children from up to three regular groups from the same age group may interact, provided that the total number of children will not exceed 28. All pupils and staff members will wear masks at all times, including on the school bus to said activities and back from them, except when eating or engaging in physical activities. Activities will be held in such a way that each staff member could teach up to three groups at most, except for physical education teachers, and provided that they will wear masks at all times and keep a distance of at least two meters between them and the pupils. All pupils will wear masks for school, including pupils in the 1st and 2nd grades, and that the pupils will eat their meals outdoors, and if that can't be done, each pupil will eat at a separate table. On the school bus, a separation between groups will be maintained by means of a row of empty seats between the front and back of the school bus.

description:
"The Israeli Ministry of Health approved new regulation for the educational system 1. Practical training or practical studies may be held in a higher education establishment or vocational training establishment that cannot be administered by online learning due to the need for equipment or infrastructures essential for learning.

2. Up to 10% of the students in those establishments may have access to infrastructures or equipment essential for participating in online learning. 

3. Studies will be held in regular capsules, with teaching staff may alternate between up to three groups. 

4. Outdoor activities may be held with one staff member and up to 19 students, including an assistant to a student who requires assistance. It should be stressed: Said assistant is to be counted in the maximum permitted the number of participants in said activities."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Some educational relaxation in Israel as of 11 Feb 2021. The opening of preschools and 1st through 4th grades in green and yellow localities. In borderline-orange localities, with an index score of 6.5 and lower, in which the vaccination rate among people 50 and older is over 70% - school activities in the same outline as in green and yellow localities. In all other localities: Educational activities will be permitted outdoors, in groups of up to 10 people (including the teacher). Borderline-orange localities will be given priority in the Magen Education program (coronavirus tests among school pupils).

description:
In Israel, 21 Feb 2021:

"The 5th and 6th grades as well as 11th and 12th grades will go back to school in local authorities and areas designated as yellow and green according to the Traffic Light model, as well as in local authorities and areas designated as orange, whose index score is 7 at most and with a vaccination rate of at least 70% among those aged 50 and older.
Hebrew classes for olim will reopen.
The 13th and 14th grades in recognized technical colleges will reopen according to the same reopening model as in schools. 
Classroom learning activities will be held in technical colleges serving as a continuing education program for at-risk youth throughout Israel. 
The permitted quota for holding outdoor learning activities will be increased from 10 people per group to 20.
Youth movements and organizations will be permitted to hold outdoor activities in the same reopening model as in schools.
External operators will be permitted to enter preschools and schools.
Single-day tours will be permitted for educational programs cleared for reopening
Boarding schools will be allowed to resume pre-lockdown open program activities, in groups of up to 18 pupils, in such a way as to allow the unhindered entry and exit to and from the boarding school."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Types of people on school premises are limited (e.g. no parents),Special provisions for all students in a school (e.g. students in primary school do not have to social distance),Other conditions not listed above (please provide detail in the text entry)

description: Schools will reopen in all green, yellow and orange-designated localities in Israel as of 11 March 2021. The Ministry of Health recommends that schools will also reopen in orange-designated localities. Establishments where 90 percent of all returning 11th and 12th grade pupils are either vaccinated or recovered will not be required to follow the capsule outline. In red-designated localities in which the entire education system is closed, establishments where 75 percent or higher of all 11th and 12th grade pupils are either vaccinated or recovered will be allowed to reopen schools for them and will be required to follow the capsule outline.

description: Some further educational restrictions are to be lifted in Israel as of 21 March. The Times of Israel reports:  "In what will be the fourth step of rolling back the lockdown, ministers also approved lifting some restrictions from the education system, raising the number of students allowed to participate in outdoor events organized by kindergartens and schools from 20 to 50.    "Teaching staff and outside teachers who have presented their Green Pass to a school principal will no longer be limited in the number of different groups of students they can work with.    "Youth movement trips, including overnight stays, will be permitted for those aged 16 or older, on the condition that at least 90% of participants have a Green Pass.    "The pod system, which limits the number of students who study together, is to be canceled for 3rd graders who will study as a full class, as is already the case for grades 1-2. However, third graders in aftercare will not be permitted to mix with students from other classes."
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Regular cleaning and sanitary procedures applied to classrooms (e.g. classrooms must be aired out after each class),Other conditions not listed above (please provide detail in the text entry)

description:
In Israel, A nation-wide curfew will be put in place from Thursday the 25th of February 2021, until Saturday 27th 2021, where from 8:30 p.m. to 5 a.m. on those days.

> Travel more than 1,000 meters from homes for any reason not considered essential 
> Staying or visiting another person’s home 
> Operating a public-facing business that is not considered essential 
> Parties (at night and during the day)

All of the above are forbidden, and those who break these rules are subject to fines of up to NIS 500.

The rules do not apply in neighborhoods where the residents are largely not Jewish, such as in east Jerusalem (this is to counter the effects of a Jewish Holiday- Purim).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Yes the curfew times differ depending on the day of the week
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
"Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced late Monday [March 16, 2020] an emergency framework as a preventive measure against the new coronavirus.   

Netanyahu said in a televised statement that the public sector will carry out its duty in line with the state of emergency, according to local media.

The decision will take effect Wednesday," March 18, 2020. The initial state of emergency lasted until June 15. On June 16, the Knesset extended the state of emergency through July 31. UPDATE: On June 16, the Knesset voted to extend the state of emergency for 45 days until July 31.

description:
Israel is allowing more outbound international travel. Starting 16.8.2020, Israelis may fly to 3 countries – Bulgaria, Croatia, and Greece.

Greece: Greece will admit 600 Israelis in total, to be distributed between Thessaloniki, Athens, Corfu, and Crete. Passengers to Greece will be required to undergo coronavirus tests in Israel, and upon arrival in Greece, they will be necessary to stay in the hotel until their test results arrive, up to 48 hours at most.

Bulgaria: Israelis arriving in Bulgaria will be required to undergo coronavirus tests in Israel 72 hours ahead of their flight. Upon arrival in Bulgaria, they will not be required to undergo coronavirus tests or to quarantine.

Croatia: Israelis wishing to enter Croatia will be required to undergo coronavirus tests in Israel 48 hours ahead of their flight. Upon arrival in Croatia, they will not be required to undergo coronavirus tests or to quarantine. They should arrive at the airport with a certificate stating that they tested negative for coronavirus.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Israel has added the UAE, Thailand, Ireland, Taiwan, Portugal, Norway, Australia, SIngapore, and Uruguay to their list of "green countries," meaning that Israeli citizens may travel home from those countries without being required to isolate.
The list of green countries already included Italy, the UK, Georgia, Germany, Hong Kong, Jordan, Latvia, Lithuania, New Zealand, Estonia, Canada, Rwanda, Denmark, Slovenia, and Austria, as well as Greece, Bulgaria, and Croatia, where Israelis may travel without quarantining or isolating at all.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: Outbound passengers must follow their destination's requirements or take a COVID-19 test in Israel at their expense for 297 NIS in hospitals throughout the country. This must be done no more than 72 hours or the destination country's requirements before the flight, whichever is less.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Authorities in Israel have announced restrictions on outbound flights until October 10, as part of the nationwide lockdown imposed to limit the spread of COVID-19. Individuals will be permitted to take flights out of the country provided tickets were booked prior to the total lockdown going into place on Friday, September 25.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Israel is easing restrictions on outbound flights, after weeks of a nationwide lockdown that restricted air travel. Travelers can purchase tickets for departing flights without restrictions and must have negative COVID-19 results from a test performed within 72 hours of their flight. Travelers arriving in Israel from “green location” countries will not need self-isolate but are subject to lockdown restrictions. On the other hand, travelers from “red location” countries are still required to self-isolate for 14 days. Afterwards, they must follow all lockdown rules.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Israel has added the UAE, Thailand, Ireland, Taiwan, Portugal, Norway, Australia, SIngapore, and Uruguay to their list of "green countries," meaning that Israeli citizens may travel home from those countries without being required to isolate.
The list of green countries already included Italy, the UK, Georgia, Germany, Hong Kong, Jordan, Latvia, Lithuania, New Zealand, Estonia, Canada, Rwanda, Denmark, Slovenia, and Austria, as well as Greece, Bulgaria, and Croatia, where Israelis may travel without quarantining or isolating at all. UPDATE: The following countries joined the list of green destinations: China, Australia, Uruguay, United Arab Emirates, Seychelles Islands, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Taiwan, Japan, Norway, New Zealand, Singapore, Fiji, Finland, Cuba, South Korea, Rwanda and Thailand. Returning passengers to Israel from green destinations will not be required to self-isolate. Denmark removed from the list of green distination to the list of red destinations, and passengers returning from Denmark have to self-isolate for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)

description: Effective Sunday (7.3.2021), up to 3,000 Israeli citizens will be allowed to enter Israel every day, according to the air travel outline and to the scope of flights that will be determined by the Ministry of Transportation in coordination with the Ministry of Health. This quota will also include passengers entering through the land border checkpoints, according to the outline to be coordinated between the Ministry of Transportation and the Ministry of Interior. The Ministers of Transportation and Health will deliver a report in every Cabinet session and draw recommendations for modifications as needed. description: "Israel is once again expected to push off allowing individual tourists into the country amid concerns over rising COVID-19 morbidity, according to a television report on Saturday. "The postponement would see the return of general tourism move from August to September, according to Channel 13 news. "Israel has been allowing some tour groups into the country in recent months, but not tourists travelling independently. It had initially planned to reopen to the latter in May, but Health Ministry recommendations pushed the plans to July, then August, and that date is now expected to be moved back until September." Reports Times of Israel 10 July.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Effective July 12, 2021, entry to foreigners policy remains (entry restricted - Exceptions Committee approval required). Changes to travel restrictions for Israeli citizens noted below: 
"The Ministry of Health updates that in accordance with the assessment of the situation that took place on 6.7.21 and subject to government approval, as of 12.7.21, the countries of Uzbekistan and Belarus will be added to the list of countries at maximum risk .    
"Therefore, as of 12.7.21 this list will include the countries: Uzbekistan, Argentina, Belarus, Brazil, South Africa, India, Mexico and Russia.    "The regulations prohibit the exit of Israeli citizens and residents (except for exceptions approved by the Exceptions Committee) to countries at maximum risk , and in addition, all those entering Israel (of any age, including recovering and vaccinated) from these countries are required to be isolated according to Ministry of Health procedures. When they entered the country.    
"The aforesaid is valid until 25.7.21 and will be extended as necessary in accordance with the level of morbidity in each of the countries."

description:
The COVID-19 Cabinet Resolution to  recategorize the UK (Great Britain), Georgia, Cyprus and Turkey as locations with the highest COVID-19 risk is in effect as of July 30, 2021. 
Traveling to destinations with the highest COVID-19 risk requires permission from the Exceptions Committee and it is expected that the number of travelers to these destinations will decrease. However, the large number of travelers returning from these destinations cannot be accommodated in Terminal 1. Therefore, in an inter-ministerial metting held in Ben Gurion International Airport, headed by the COVID-19 Commissioner, it was resolved to divert some arrivals from destinations with the highest COVID-19 risk to Terminal 3 in a controlled and managed manner, in accordance with infection rates among travelers returning from these locations.

The Shiba Medical Center is preparing to receive the Israelis in a separate unit manned by a designated team specifically assigned to this task. During their stay at the designated unit, the Shiba Medical Center will continue its regular activity with complete separation – both physical and infrastructural – from the quarantine area."

description: In Israel, "the health and defense ministries have launched a project to manufacture reusable masks made of high-density cotton, a report said Friday [April 17, 2020]. The face masks are designed to fit everyone, including children and bearded men." In Israel, Orthodox Jews, religious Muslims, and Christian clergy tend to grow long beards, which made it difficult for them to wear the standard masks. Israel had already produced 1,000,000 cotton masks by April 19, but not all from this particular initiative.

description: Who should I notify about entering home quarantine?  By law, you must notify the Ministry of Health in Israel that you are entering quarantine through the online form or by calling the Ministry of Health hotline at *5400. By 1 November 2020, the Israeli military plans to employ over 2,000 soldiers specifically to perform contact tracing.

description:
"On January 26, 2020, in Israel: ""The The Ministry stresses that whoever arrived from China and does not exhibit any symptoms of the disease does not need to get tested. In case that a respiratory disease (fever and coughing) appears during travel to China or within 14 days after the last stay in China: 
Refer to your treating physician at the HMO or go to the emergency room as soon as possible. Call in advance and notify emergency room staff that the patient suffers from respiratory disease and that the patient stayed in China, before arriving at the hospital or the offices of your treating physician at the HMO. Avoid traveling in public transportation. Until tested by a physician, keep your mouth and nose covered by a surgical mask or by another available cloth. Upon entering the clinic or the emergency room, promptly report the symptoms of the disease to the receptionist or the nurse on duty, and disclose the possible connection to a stay in China about 14 days before the appearance of the symptoms."""
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Travel in a restricted area is permitted for the following cases only:    Going to work or a job interview, and returning from work  Getting food, medicines, and essential products and receiving essential services  Receiving medical care  Donating blood  Attending Demonstrations  Attending Legal proceedings  Going to the Knesset  Receiving welfare services  Participating in sport activities alone or with the same partner each time, or with people who live together, up to 500 meters from the place of residence, or at a larger distance as defined by the Ministerial Committee  Leaving a place of residence alone or with people who live together, for a short time, up to 100 meters from the place of residence, or at a larger distance as defined by the Ministerial Committee  Going to Mikveh (ritual baths)  Going to prayer services, funerals, brits, or weddings  Receiving medical assistance for one’s self or assisting a person with difficulty or distress  Transfer of a minor whose parents live separately between parents  Transfer of a minor whose parents live separately when one parent is required for essential purposes as specified in the regulations, providing there is no other responsible supervision available for the minor.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Israel is enforcing new lockdown guidelines on April 1; Going out in public is not allowed, except for one of the following purposes:
Going to and returning from the work place, as permitted by regulations
Purchase of food, medicines, essential products and receiving vital services
Receiving medical service
Blood donation
Receiving welfare services
Providing medical or other assistance to another person
An individual, or people who live in the same household, may go out for a short time and up to a distance of 100 meters
For purposes of immersion in a women’s mikveh with a prearranged appointment.
Transfer of a minor to educational facilities, solely for children of essential employees and special facilities (in accordance with Public Health Ordinance order)
Transfer of a minor, whose parents live separately, by one of his parents to the home of the other parent
Transfer of a minor whose guardian must leave for an essential need where there is no responsible person to watch the child
Legal processes
Demonstrations
Going to the Knesset

description:
On the 14th of April, 2020. The government of Israel approved a nationwide lockdown for the end of the Passover holiday and the Mimouna festival, which will see intercity travel banned and bakeries shuttered until Thursday morning, to stem the spread of the coronavirus.
From Tuesday at 5 p.m. until Thursday at 5 a.m., Israelis will be barred from leaving their hometowns, or in the case of Jerusalem, the neighborhoods in which they live, according to the restrictions.
Bakeries and restaurants will remain closed until Thursday morning at 2 a.m., though supermarkets will be permitted to operate from Wednesday evening and food deliveries are permitted. This was to prevent crowds from gathering after Passover ends to purchase breads and other “unleavened” goods that many traditionally refrain from consuming during the holiday.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Israel will enter a three-week nationwide lockdown, starting Friday September 18, 2020, to curb the spread of the novel coronavirus after a second-wave surge in new cases. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday announced the lockdown ahead of the Jewish holiday season, which starts with the Jewish New Year on September 18 and ends with the Tabernacles holiday on October 9. During the lockdown, Israelis will have to stay within 500 metres of their homes but can travel to workplaces that will be allowed to operate on a limited basis.

description: Israel is enforcing tighter lockdown measures on the lockdown that was imposed on Friday, September 18th. From Friday, September 25th Israel will be going into a full lockdown. This lockdown will include closing all non-essential businesses, only allowing people to gather in family groups, and the existing limit prohibiting travel over 1km (0.6mi) from home except for essential purposes will now also apply to protests and worship. Schools will remain closed and synagogues will close on Friday, but will be allowed to reopen at a limited capacity for Yom Kippur between Sunday, September 27, and Monday, September 28. The tightened measures are expected to be in place until at least October 10.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

The tightened measures are expected to be in place until at least October 10. UPDATE: On the 18th of October, 2020. The Israeli government will begin easing the nationwide lockdown in place to control the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). description: Israel's coronavirus czar Prof. Gamzu announced plans for  a “traffic light” system for gauging coronavirus levels in different parts of Israel on July 28. His “traffic light” program creates a system for labeling coronavirus levels in different parts of the country, color-coding municipalities like traffic lights: green, yellow, orange and red. His idea is to let the municipalities take a more active role in managing their constituents and partnering with the Health Ministry and the IDF to stop the spread of infection. This program was also approved and is expected to go into effect on September 1. Starting September 1, restrictions on communities will be determined by what color "zone" they fall in, either green, yellow, orange, or red.

description: Mayor of Nazareth, Israel, Ali Salam said that "On March 8, I formed a committee and we met with homeland security and the police, religious leaders, the directors of Nazareth’s three hospitals, and we worked together and came out with one voice, calling on residents to follow the social-distancing instructions." He added that "we drove around the city in a car equipped with a loudspeaker, 24 hours a day, with my voice urging the residents not to leave their homes and to follow the guidelines of the health minister and the prime minister and the mayor."
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
Israel's "Health Ministry announced Sunday [March 22, 2020] the launch of a new smartphone app to help to prevent the spread of the deadly coronavirus — by enabling users to know if they crossed paths with someone who has been diagnosed with the virus."
"Called Hamagen (The Shield), the app reveals if a user was, over the previous 14 days, in close proximity to anyone who has been diagnosed  with the virus, the ministry said in a statement."
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On February 22, 2020, it was announced that "following a report received from South Korea regarding 9 tourists from a group that recently stayed in Israel between 8.2.2020 – 15.2.2020 and subsequently identified as coronavirus patients upon returning to South Korea. 
The Ministry of Health wishes to instruct the Israeli public as follows:
 
1. Anyone who came in close contact (at a distance of less than two meters and for at least 15 minutes) with members of this group according to the dates and location detailed below, is requested to enter home quarantine for a duration of 14 days since last date of contact with the group and report this at the Ministry of Health's website or Kol Habriut Hotline, *5400.  Furthermore, should you develop the symptoms of the disease (fever over 38, coughing, or other respiratory symptoms) seek medical assistance in accordance with the Ministry of Health's instructions on the website, all the while calling ahead of time and following the Ministry's guidelines.
2. Anyone who was in the same locations at the same time detailed below as the group *but without close contact* is not required to enter home quarantine but is asked to remain vigilant to the symptoms of the disease (fever over 38, coughing or other respiratory symptoms)."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On February 28, 2020, in Israel, it was announced that "a passenger [that tested positive for Coronavirus] arrived on commercial Turkish Airline flight TK53 from Tokyo to Istanbul, and on flight TK84 from Istanbul to Tel Aviv that landed in Israel at 08:55.
All passengers who were onboard the flight that landed this morning and who were on the same flight as this person must enter home quarantine immediately for 14 days, and report this at the Ministry of Health's website or at Kol Habriut Hotline at *5400."

description:
In Israel, on February 28, 2020: "The Ministry of Health announces that the epidemiologic investigation has ended. The findings specifiy the places the patient visited and at that times:

El Al flight number LY381 on 21.2.20 departing from Israel at 06:00
El Al flight Iy 382 landed in Israel on 23.2.20 at 16:10
Sunday 23.2 "The Red Pirate" store, Or Yehuda from 18:00 to 22:00
Monday 24.2 "The Red Pirate" store, Or Yehuda from 08:30 - 24:00
Tuesday 25.2 "The Red Pirate" store, Or Yehuda 08:30 - 24:00
Monday, February 24, at the "Irus" Synagogue on Noga Street, Irus, from 06:00-07:00

Any person who visited these places and had close contact - being less than 2 meters for 15 minutes or more - of the patient, must be placed under 14-day home quarantine and send a questionnaire to the Ministry of Health or the Health Ministry Hotline *5400."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Beginning around March 17, the Israeli Defense Forces began operating quarantine hotels for people to quarantine upon contracting Coronavirus or entering the country. On May 11, the IDF eased the hotel regulations, permitting people with the means to self-isolate at home to do so. On August 11, the hotel quarantine policy was extended until August 31.

description:
Beginning around March 17, the Israeli Defense Forces began operating quarantine hotels for people to quarantine upon contracting Coronavirus or entering the country. On May 11, the IDF eased the hotel regulations, permitting people with the means to self-isolate at home to do so. On August 11, the hotel quarantine policy was extended until August 31.

The IDF closed 7 of the 28 hotels between August 16-August 27. UPDATE: The IDF will have closed 7 of 28 hotels by Thursday, August 27, 2020.

description: Israel's Ministry of Health updated its quarantine regulations. Whereas a 14 day quarantine was enforced previously, as of July 22, 2020, quarantine is only required for 10 days since the beginning of symptoms or a positive test result, including at least 3 days without symptoms. A second test showing a negative result is not necessary.

Countries on the "red" list will be required to quarantine for 2 weeks. This policy will go into affect on August 16th.

description: As of September 28, 2020, anyone tested positive or required to self-isolate will not be returning home after Yom Kippur and will be staying in specially-designated coronavirus yeshivas or follow-up yeshivas. As part of the provisions of the capsule settlement between the yeshivas and the ultra-orthodox desk, coronavirus tests were carried out. In yeshivas that do not operate according to the capsule settlement, we intend to carry out tests on Tuesday and Wednesday.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective October 2, 2020, all arriving passengers, including U.S. citizens, may be subject to health screening and/or a mandatory 14-day quarantine in a Government of Israel-established quarantine center. Those who demonstrate the ability to maintain proper home isolation (such as those with a housing of their own or a completely separate housing unit with no other occupants) may be allowed to undergo their 14-day required isolation at home or another suitable location available to them. Individuals who are unable to home-isolate according to regulations will be directed to hotel isolation at the expense of the State of Israel. Arriving passengers will not be allowed to return to home isolation via public transportation with the exception of taxis (in accordance with regulations on masks/open windows). For more information, contact the Israeli Ministry of Health. Please refer to the Israeli Ministry of Health’s instructions for home quarantine and health precaution instructions, or call *5400 (in Israel only).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Israel is reducing the quarantine period to 10 days, on the condition that those in isolation test negative for the coronavirus twice. One test is to be taken at the beginning of the quarantine period and the second taken nine days after the initial possible exposure to the virus. The two tests must be taken at least 24 hours apart. However, travelers entering the country and Israelis exposed to confirmed virus carriers are still required to self-isolate for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective December 21, 2020, citizens returning from Denmark, South Africa, and UK must enter mandatory quarantine at designated hotels for 14 days. Authorities in Israel have banned the entry of non-citizens traveling from Denmark, South Africa, and the UK. In response to a new strain of coronavirus disease COVID-19 discovered primarily in the southeast of England, including London. Returning citizens from the aforementioned countries must enter a mandatory quarantine at designated hotels for 14 days, during which the individuals will undergo two COVID-19 tests. The person will be allowed to exit quarantine on the tenth day upon producing two negative results.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective from January 8, 2021, inbound passengers required to go into isolation upon arriving Israel, who stayed in South Africa, Botswana, Zambia or Lesotho in the 14 days prior to their arrival in Israel, will be required to go into isolation in motels operated on behalf of the State of Israel, for 10 days (with 2 Coronavirus tests to be administered) or for 14 days without Coronavirus tests.

description: As of February 10, 2021, all inbound passengers to Israel shall be required to stay in isolation in a state-designated isolation site motel . These shall remain in effect until February 21, 2021. UPDATE: Effective February 24, 2021, the Ministerial Committee for Coping with Coronavirus approved this morning (by telephone survey) the extension of the motel isolation requirement for returning international passengers from all destinations until Tuesday, March 9, 2021. The isolation duration is 14 days without testing for coronavirus or 10 days upon submitting to two coronavirus tests and testing negative in both, in accordance with the current protocol.

description: As of July 13, 2021, coronavirus quarantine will be cut down to just seven days, ministers decided on Tuesday, as the Health Ministry pushed sought to tighten other restrictions in order to curb a resurgence of COVID-19 cases. Unvaccinated people or those who have not already had COVID-19 and who have been exposed to a known virus carrier will be required to spend just a week in isolation, rather than the current 10-14 days. The same will apply to unvaccinated returnees from abroad.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Israel is reducing the quarantine period to 10 days, on the condition that those in isolation test negative for the coronavirus twice. One test is to be taken at the beginning of the quarantine period and the second taken nine days after the initial possible exposure to the virus. The two tests must be taken at least 24 hours apart. However, travelers entering the country and Israelis exposed to confirmed virus carriers are still required to self-isolate for 14 days. UPDATE: Effective July 15, 2021, The isolation period can be shortened, if the results of two coronavirus tests are negative. First test to be conducted as soon as possible upon entering isolation. Second test to be conducted on the 7th day of isolation or later and at least 24 hours after the first test. When you receive the negative result of the second test, it is possible to finish isolation. It is not necessary to wait for a text message (SMS) from the Ministry of Health instructing you to finish isolation. The full isolation period, without shortening, is 14 days from the date of last contact with the confirmed coronavirus case or from the time of arrival in Israel.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

On 19th of March, 2020. The government of Israel has prohibited the operation of Clubs, bars, pubs, banquet halls, fitness centers, swimming pools, water parks, zoos, safaris, petting zoos, bathhouses, cinemas, theaters, cultural institutions, playgrounds, amusement parks, businesses for the non-medical care of the body, exhibition and concert halls, fairgrounds, public boats, cable-cars, museums, nature reserves, national parks, libraries, tourist attractions and heritage sites.

The Government of the State of Israel approved emergency regulations for additional restrictions on going out in public during the seventh day of the Passover holiday and “Mimouna” celebrations, during the period between Wednesday (April 15, 2020) at 19:00 and Thursday (April 16, 2020) at 02:00, food stores with will be closed with the exception of supermarkets which may be open. The bakeries in the supermarkets will be closed during this time.
Food deliveries will continue to be permitted.
The above restrictions will not apply to localities whose majority is not Jewish.

description: On April 19, 2020, the workplace emergency regulations in Israel have been relaxed: "The industry, manufacturing, and services sectors may resume working at a capacity of 30% of their workforce strength or up to 10 employees in the workplace at the same time, whichever is higher." There are indeed several rules for employees coming to the workplace, as for instance taking the temperature at the entrance and keeping distance to other employees. UPDATE: The original workplace regulations declared on April 7th allowed no employees in the workplace. This was extended until April 19th and relaxed on April 7th to a maximum of employees of 15% of the workforce in the workplace. On April 19th, the regulations have been extended until April 30th, 2020, with a relaxation of now 30% of the workforce able to come to the workplace.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 19th, 2020, in Israel, an amendment to the emergency regulations that restricted non-essential businesses were relaxed. The reopening of several businesses and services is subject to compliance with conditions such as taking the temperature of anyone walking into the business; marking a distance of 2 meters between customers etc.. UPDATE: The closure of businesses announced on March 15th, was relaxed for some shops and services. The emergency regulations (Restrictions of Activity) will be extended until Sunday, May 3rd, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Israel declares on May 7th 2020 all non-essential business' are permitted to reopen under certain regulations. "Including Libraries, all kinds of non-medical bodily treatment, alternative medicine, hotels and guest houses, nature reserves, national heritage sites, and national parks, zoos, and safaris. Furthermore, it is permitted to open swimming pools for competitive athletes and therapeutic activities." UPDATE: The original order was was for closure of all non-essential business' has now been relaxed, and business' are permitted to reopen under certain regulations

description:
Israel on May 26 announced that restaurants, bars, pubs, pools, youth centers, community centers, and other non-essential tourist attractions will be allowed to reopen starting May 27, subject to restrictions on capacity, physical distancing, masking, and hygiene. 

Masks must be worn at all times except when eating. Restaurants/bars with capacity greater than 100 may only operate at 85% capacity. Business owners must maintain a ratio of 7 sq meters per customer. Pools must maintain a ratio of 6 sq meters of space for each customer.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Israeli authorities announced that cinemas, are set to gradually open on June 14. Movie-goers will be required to sit two seats apart, and the number of people in each screening will be determined by the movie hall’s size. No updates have been given reading the reopening of theaters. Event halls, too, are set to open on June 14. Guests will be required to wear facemasks except when they are eating or drinking, and their temperature will be taken upon arrival.

description:
Israel's "Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Finance Minister Moshe Kahlon Monday night [March 30] presented an 80 billion shekel ($22.3 billion) economic program to help the economy get through the impact of the coronavirus pandemic."

4 elements of plan:

"10 billion shekels in extra health care spending.

About 20 billion shekels for a safety net for salaried workers and the self-employed, of which 17 billion is slated for jobless benefits.

For small, medium-sized and large businesses, 32 billion shekels in aid.

About 8 billion shekels to boost the economy after the crisis eases."
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Non-essential workers (please note their occupation in the text entry where applicable)
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On the 17th of July, 2020. The government of Israel has announced Weekend restrictions (to take effect from 17:00 on Fridays until 05:00 on Sunday)

There will be no restriction on leaving one's home.
During the weekend, being on beaches shall be prohibited (except for this weekend, 17-18 July, when beaches shall remain open).
During the weekend, stores, malls, open-air markets, hair salons/barbershops, beauty parlors, libraries, petting zoos, museums and display spaces, pools, tourist attractions and cable cars shall be closed.
This restriction shall not apply to stores providing essential services: Places for the sale of food, pharmacies and stores most business of which is the sale of hygiene products, opticians and labs for the repair of communications devices.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On July 16, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus cabinet announced that "Food courts in workplaces will be closed to visitors. Takeout is allowed.
> Gyms and studios used for sports training or choreography will be closed, with the exception of competitive and olympic sports, according to existing regulations
> Cafés, restaurants and other food-related businesses will be closed to the public. Takeout and food delivery are allowed.
> Hotel restaurants' visitor capacity will be limited to 35%."

description:
On July 16, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus cabinet announced that "Food courts in workplaces will be closed to visitors. Takeout is allowed.
> Gyms and studios used for sports training or choreography will be closed, with the exception of competitive and olympic sports, according to existing regulations
> Cafés, restaurants and other food-related businesses will be closed to the public. Takeout and food delivery are allowed.
> Hotel restaurants' visitor capacity will be limited to 35%."

On July 17, the cabinet decided to allow restaurants to serve customers until July 21 at 5:00 am. On July 21, the Knesset Coronavirus Committee reversed that decision and allowed restaurants to reopen. UPDATE: The Knesset Coronavirus Committee reversed the decision on restaurants closing, allowing them to to open again on July 21.

description:

description: Israel is placing maximum capacities for public places and places of business: One person per 7 square meters or as per the restriction on gatherings (whichever is higher). Exceptions: Eating establishments (20 people in a closed space in a structure and up to 30 people outside); eating establishments in hotels (up to 35% capacity according to the business license); group therapy in a social welfare framework (up to 15 people); pools and mikvaot (in the water, up to 1 person per 6 square meters). Signs regarding the permitted number of persons must be posted; the number of those present must be regulated.

description: On the 6th of September, 2020. Israel's Ministerial Committee on Declaring Restricted Zones voted to approve a nightly curfew between 19:00 to 05:00 (local time) in 40 'red' cities across Israel. The measure will come into effect from 19:00 on Monday, September 7, in the areas worst-hit by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), with a detailed list of affected areas expected to be released on Monday morning. In areas where the measures apply non-essential businesses will be required to close during curfew hours.

description: On Friday, 18 September 2020. The government of Israel implemented full closure of all businesses that receive the public in the fields of commerce, culture, recreation and domestic tourism, including swimming pools. Gyms and restaurants (except for essential services, places for the sale of food, pharmacies, opticians or stores that deal mostly in hygiene products, stores for essential home maintenance products, communications products and medical devices). Businesses, including restaurants, shall be permitted to operate delivery services only.

description:
On the 1st of November, 2020. The government of Israel has permitted Establishments offering non-medical bodily treatments may be opened, such as hair salons and beauty salons, as well as establishments
providing alternative medicine, subject to the requirements stipulated by the regulations, such as the requirement to call ahead and
schedule an appointment. It should be stressed that such non-medical bodily treatments also include such treatments as equineassisted therapy, psychotherapy, and aquatic therapy.

description: On the 30th of November, 2020. In Israel, The Ministerial Coronavirus Committee approved the amendment to the outline of the pilot for reopening the malls as follows: Regarding the maximum permitted capacity in the mall premises, capacity is changed from a ratio of one person per 7 square meters to a ratio of one person per 15 square meters.    Regarding the surface area of the stores themselves, it will be determined that in addition to the rule stipulated by the main regulations (according to which, capacity will be at a ratio of one person per 7 square meters and up to 10 people in total) in "large" stores whose surface area exceeds 150 square meters, maximum permitted capacity will be at a ratio of one person per 15 square meters (without setting a numerical capping on the number of patrons. Calculation of surface area for matters of maximum permitted capacity in the mall (in the common areas) will not include the surface area of a public and business establishment forbidden from operating inside a mall (such as the surface area of a movie theater inside the mall).

Beyond the aforesaid restriction, employers will be required to continue meeting the conditions of the Purple Badge.

description: On the 27th of December, 2020. The government of Israel has closed public and business places other than essential stores: Food, hygiene, optic stores, pharmacies, electrical appliance stores and stores selling products needed for essential home repairs. In addition, there will be closure of accommodation units and Guesthouses/Bed-and-Breakfests (Zimmers), zoos, nature reserve safari, national parks, national sites and memorial sites; premises providing non-medical care, including hairdressers and premises providing beauty and cosmetic treatments; places providing complementary medicine treatment; drive-ins for watching movies; malls, retail markets and museums, in addition to prohibiting the opening of restaurants/establishments/premises for food Take-Away.

description:
On the 21st of February, 2021. The government of Israel approved the following opening restrictions apply to markets and malls, Capacity restrictions: At a ratio of one person per each 15 square meters. The operator will install a digital adjustment apparatus to count the number of people entering the mall. Mall owners are required to place between 2-5 ushers serving as coronavirus prefects, tasked with ensuring that everyone in place follows the coronavirus guidance. Mall owners are also required to take actions for preventing gatherings in the mall's premises, including at the entrance to stores and at the entrance to the mall, including taking measures to enforce the distancing policy in the waiting lines by placing visual cues on the floor and physical distancing means. Visitors may not sit down for meals in the mall's premises, there will be no dining tables and chairs in the mall's premises, access will be denied to dining tables permanently fastened to the floor, if there are any such tables. Mall owners or operators will place prominent signs reminding visitors that eating in the mall's premises is forbidden.
Food stands may not be placed in the mall's premises and fairs may not be held. Mall owners will separate, inasmuch as possible, to keep the mall's entrances and exits separate. Inasmuch as possible, mall owners will take actions to make sure that the air is circulated at least 3 times per hour.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Restriction of number of customers

description:
On the 21st of February, 2021. The government of Israel has allowed Gyms to reopen with the following restrictions The establishment's owner or operator will ensure that a distance of no less than 2 meters is maintained between machines and patrons during both person training and group training, or that dividers are placed between machines with fewer than 2 meters between them.
The establishment's owner or operator will only admit patrons based on registration in advance, will not operate any Jacuzzis or saunas in place and will make sure that the establishment is properly cleaned and sanitized."

description:
On the 21st of February, 2021. The government of Israel has allowed Hotels to open under the following restrictions: Hotels, excluding the dining room area, may be opened for recovered or vaccinated individuals, as well as for minor younger than 16 who presented negative test results to a coronavirus test taken up to 48 hours before arriving in the hotels (air crew or foreign nationals staying in Israel in their line of duty may be admitted subject to presenting test results as mentioned). Hotel admission includes admission to the common areas in the hotel (and excluding the dining room, as mentioned).
Hotel managers will be required to opt for their mode of operations, whether as a substitute residence, which excludes the use of the common areas, or as a hotel operating under the Green Pass requirements.

High-speed intercity transport will not be increased except for the "train kissing" lines such as line 480 from Tel Aviv Arlozorov to Jerusalem, and line 910 from Tel Aviv to Haifa, which will operate at least twice an hour. description:
In Israel, "some 20 national parks and nature reserves all over the country will open on Wednesday [May 6] as part of the coronavirus reopening announced Monday [May 4].

Obligatory advance registration, via a website (in Hebrew) set to open Tuesday [May 5], will ensure that the various sites adhere to Health Ministry requirements. Visitor quotas will be set for each site and the duration of visits will be limited."

"The nature parks set to open include Ma’ayan Harod (Harod Stream), Caesarea, Yarkon Tel Afek, Yarkon Park, Apollonia, Beit Guvrin, Herodium, Castel, the Ein Gedi archaeological park, Masada and Ein Habesor.

The list of nature reserves includes Banias, Snir Stream, Ayun Stream, Yehudiya, Ein Afek, Hula, Taninim Stream, Enot Tsukim, Ein Gedi and the Zin Cliffs Nature Reserve."

description:
In Israel starting on Monday April 20, urban and suburban transportation (buses only, not railways) will double in all parts of the country, from 25% of activity in which it currently operates to 50% of activity. High-speed intercity transport will not be increased except for the "train kissing" lines such as line 480 from Tel Aviv Arlozorov to Jerusalem, and line 910 from Tel Aviv to Haifa, which will operate at least twice an hour. Passengers will be required to wear a mask, there will be a limit of 20 passengers on each bus, and passengers will not be allowed in the first row near the driver. 

This policy's ending was announced on May 24. From Thursday, May 28, intercity buses will be permitted to operate at 75 percent capacity. Additionally, Israel's railways will return to full operational capacity on Monday, June 8. UPDATE: The original policy restricted buses to 50%, they will now be allowed to operate at 75% capacity. Trains were up until this point not allowed to run, they will now be allowed to operate at full capacity starting June 8.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On the 17th of September, 2020. The government of Israel has approved regulations that restrict the number of employees in the public sector. The regulations state that the number of employees in government ministries, local authorities, and religious councils will not exceed ten employees or 50% of the manpower in place at the same time, whichever is higher. Starting Friday, 18.9.20 at 14:00, the public sector will be working according to an emergency protocol that will allow the provision of essential services for the citizens but will limit the number of in-office workers to 50% the manpower quota. All other employees will be working, in as much as possible, from home or as part of employment agreements between the Director of Salary and Employment Agreements and the Chairperson of the New General Federation of Labor (Histadrut).

description: On the 1st of November, 2020. The government of Israel has permitted the openning of Social services programs and other services listed under article 11(B) of the Law, not just for essential social therapy. This amendment will allow, among other things, to operate services that are provided as part of day centers and community centers for senior citizens, or services aimed at alleviating senior citizens' loneliness, including those services that are not offered as part of local authorities' social services basket and including libraries for blind and visually impaired individuals.

description:
On the 21st of February, 2021. The government of Israel approved the opening of museums with the following measures must be adhered to: Visitors will register in advance; Ushers will be appointed; Guided tours will be held with no more than 10 people and arranged ahead of time;  Inasmuch as possible, visitors' route through the museum or the exhibit will be according to a previously charted course and in one direction;
In museums or exhibits where there are displays which encourage visitors to touch them, the museum or exhibit's operator will place an usher for every few active displays to remind visitors of the distancing requirement and the gathering restrictions and sanitize the displays frequently."

description:
On the 14th of June, 2020. The government of Israel has permitted the resumption of cultural events in the following manner:
It will be possible to hold theater shows and performances in event halls across the country.
Events can be held at a maximal capacity of 75 percent.
Required: Social distancing, wearing masks, and maintaining hygiene.
Tickets for shows could only be purchased online.
A party of people who ordered several tickets in a single booking can be seated together in a capsule of sorts. One seat will be maintained between capsules.
There will be no intermissions during shows.
Body temperature will be taken before entering the complex. 
* It should be noted that if there are more than 500 people, the permission of the Minister of Culture and Sport's Director General after consultations with the Ministry of Health is required.

* Regarding visits to museums, it has been agreed that starting 27.5, the capacity will be increased to one visitor per 7 square meters, as opposed to one visitor per 15 square meters required today.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced on July 2, 2020 that, beginning July 3, crowds in closed spaces including synagogues, event halls, bars, and nightclubs will be limited to 50 people. Other closed spaces, including private homes and places of work, business, and shopping, will be limited to a capacity of 20 people. Previously, event halls were limited to 250 people and restaurants were permitted full capacity up to 100 people, or 85% capacity past 100 people.

description:
Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet decided on the following restriction on July 6, 2020:

"1. Event halls- 50 people
2. pubs and bars - 50 people
3. Restaurants - 20 people sitting inside, up to 30 outside
4. Synagogues - 19 people
5. Gyms and public pools - closed
6. Cultural performances - closed
7. Organized sporting events - without fans
8. hotels and tourism - clubs and bars closed, hotel restaurants 20 people (closed seating)
9. Summer camps - closed for children from fourth grade
10. Buses - up to 20 people per bus, with windows open and no air-conditioning
11. Gatherings - up to 20 people, two meters apart with masks
12. Government offices - 30% of staff required to work from home"
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Attendance at religious services restricted (e.g. mosque/church closings)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On July 16, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced that "gatherings will be limited to 10 people in enclosed spaces and 20 people in open spaces, with the exception of workplaces and immediate families. This restriction will apply starting Friday [July 17] at 5:00 p.m."

On August 13 the cabinet updated the rules effective August 17: up to 30 people can gather in an open space. In places of up to 80 square meters, 10 people can gather. In place over 80 square meters, 20. UPDATE: The original policy allowed only 10 people inside closed indoor spaces; this update that goes into effect August 17 allows up to 30 people to gather in an open space. In places of up to 80 square meters, 10 people can gather. In place over 80 square meters, 20.

description: The municipality of Tel Aviv, Israel, will "launch a ‘sail-in’ floating cinema under the clear night sky from August 22-28, in partnership with Tel Aviv Cinematheque. A total of 70 socially distanced boats will be available to moviegoers, adults and children alike, seeking to enjoy a night of cinematic entertainment under the stars. Boats will be distanced two meters apart at all times opposite a large screen, ensuring a safe and fun experience, and allowing all ticketholders to float away and unwind from the daily grind for at least a few hours. The event has received Health Ministry approval and will be held in strict accordance with ‘purple badge’ public health standards."

description: On the 31st of August, 2020. The government of Israel has announced Gathering restrictions extended in red areas. Under the new plan, each local authority was classified as red, orange, yellow or green, depending on the level of morbidity, and according to this division separate COVID-19 restrictions will be set. Accordingly, in red areas, for example, gatherings are limited to 20 people outdoors and 10 people indoors, while in green areas gatherings of up to 250 people outside and 100 people indoors are allowed.

description: On 25th of March, 2020. The Israeli government has closed all religious venues. The government instituted a nearly complete COVID-19 lockdown that includes the closure of all houses of worship. The directive permits 10 worshippers to pray outdoors, provided they stand at least 6 feet apart.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Other Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The Israeli Government approved new, extended emergency regulations aimed at creating "social distance" on March 25, 2020 that include inter alia:
- it is not permitted to leave a place of residence to the public space expect for special cases 
- Departure of an individual or persons living in the same place only for a short time and up to 100 meters from the place of residence
- the enforcement of regulations by the police
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
The Israeli Government approved new, extended emergency regulations aimed at creating "social distance" on March 25, 2020 that include inter alia:
- the reduction of public transport services to around 25%
- the employer is obligated to measure body temperature at the entrance to the workplace 
- the enforcement of regulations by the police UPDATE: The restrictions of the public life, initiated on March 13, were extended on March 25.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On the 21st of April, 2020. The government of Israel has announced the visitation protocol in residential settings for older adults and people with disabilities. This protocol stipulates how visits should be coordinated with the residential facilities and how the facilities should act. The goal is to allow for secure visits where a single visitor may come for a visit and bring with them some personal articles or some food for the resident. However, such visits will not be made possible in residential facilities housing task-specific wards for the treatment of Coronavirus patients.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description:
On the 28th of April, 2020. The government of Israel has announced Beginning Tuesday, April 28, 2020 at 17:00 until Wednesday, April 29, 2020 at 20:00, a person can leave their home only for the purpose of procuring medicines and essential items, receive vital services, and only in their local municipality (unless their municipality does not contain those services, in which case they can go to the nearest municipality).
During this period, public transport activity will cease.
The Ministry of Health reiterates that citizens must celebrate Independence Day in their homes. Procuring of food will not be allowed on the Eve of Independence Day and Independence Day itself. It is possible to leave the house in order to get fresh air or exercise near the home as with the regulations from the Seder night.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On the 8th of May, 2020. The government of Israel in consultation with the Ministry of Health, provided clarifications concerning sleeping arrangements for Foreign Caregivers who provide live-in care for elderly and handicapped employers, concerning living and sleeping arrangements on their weekly days of rest:

If the Foreign Caregiver wishes to sleep outside of his elderly or handicapped employer's home (which is considered the caregiver's regular home for this purpose) the Caregiver may not sleep in a communal apartment used by a group of other persons.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on visiting nursing homes/long term care facilities
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People in nursing homes/long term care facilities

description: On the 20th of May, 2020. The government of Israel has announced restrictions on the number of passengers on buses will be lifted during peak hours. The buses affected by the new directive are those that run from 7-8:30 a.m. and 1-3 p.m., when children generally travel to and from school.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Israel is allowing Extracurricular Activities, Youth Movements, and Informal Education to open. They are allowed to open under certain restrictions. In the classroom, extracurricular activities can open as long as there are 5 square meters in between every person. In the open, there must be 2 square meters between every person. In studio based activites, there must be 7 square meters between ever person.

description: Israeli authorities announced that cinemas, are set to gradually open on June 14. Movie-goers will be required to sit two seats apart, and the number of people in each screening will be determined by the movie hall’s size. No updates have been given reading the reopening of theaters. Event halls, too, are set to open on June 14. Guests will be required to wear facemasks except when they are eating or drinking, and their temperature will be taken upon arrival.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Commercial Businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 9th of July, 2020. The government of Israel and The National Authority for Public Transport have announced that as of Thursday, 09.07.2020, public transportation will operate under the following restrictions.  -Occupancy of up to 50% of the seats  -Public transport activity will end in the middle of the week at 22:00   -Public transportation will operate until the beginning of Shabbat and on Saturday evenings with up to 50% occupancy  -The activity of main lines and during rush hours will be increased  -Israel Railways will continue to operate in accordance with the existing outline of purchasing vouchers in advance  -Buses leaving from the train complexes will continue to operate even after 22:00   -Following the agreement with the Ministry of Defense, IDF servants will only board private vehicles  -It is mandatory to wear a mask while traveling
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on ridership of subways and trams
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Israel is resuming all schools under the following restricitons: 2 meters between students, including during lunchtime, wearing masks, practicing hygiene.  The higher education resumes full operation according to the Ministry of Education guidelines: 2 meters between students, wearing masks, practicing hygiene. If an area is declared a red zones, schools will be closed in that zone.  Special education operate the same as the other schools, except nursing individuals: groups of 6.  The higher education system will hold online exams (except special cases).  High religious schools, religious schools (Midrasha) and Kolels will expand operation. Restrictions: No more than 50 participants, 2 meters distance between people (except physical activities), 2 meters distance can be kept on premise, and wearing masks.  Extracurricular programs, youth movements, and informal education:  Courses, ulpan, youth movement and informal education is permitted up to grade 4. Restrictions; up to 50 participants, maintaining a 2-meter person to person distance (except when carrying out activities that necessitate contact, such as sport activities), wearing masks, indoor activities – up to 50 people may participate, provided they maintain a distance of 2 meters, or alternately if they ensure that there will be no more than one person per 7 square meters, outdoor activities – up to 50 people may participate, while maintaining a distance of 2 meters.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of July 29, "Jerusalem's [Israel] municipal government launched a new project this week aimed at encouraging the use of public parks while promoting social distancing, marking recreation spots on the grass in the form of hearts." This policy was initially implemented at Gan Haatzmaut and plans to include Gan Sacker and other large parks in the city.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: Israel is placing maximum capacities for public places and places of business: One person per 7 square meters or as per the restriction on gatherings (whichever is higher). Exceptions: Eating establishments (20 people in a closed space in a structure and up to 30 people outside); eating establishments in hotels (up to 35% capacity according to the business license); group therapy in a social welfare framework (up to 15 people); pools and mikvaot (in the water, up to 1 person per 6 square meters). Signs regarding the permitted number of persons must be posted; the number of those present must be regulated.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at All or unspecified businesses
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 9, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced a restriction on the number of passengers allowed to travel in private vehicles. The new restriction permits 2 passengers not including the driver, and one passenger for each additional row, excluding people who live together.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 11th of August, 2020. The government of Israel has restricted traveling in private vehicles to no more than two passengers in addition to the driver, and if the vehicle has more than one rear bench, of one passenger on each rear bench, except for people who live together.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation

description: Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet established a limit on the number of people in certain public spaces: one person for seven meters, or in accordance to gathering guidelines. This policy excludes restaurants (up to 20 people inside and up to 30 people outside), restaurants in a hotel (35% of capacity), and 1 person for every 6 meters in hotel swimming pools. Businesses must post signs with these restrictions to inform guests.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 9, 2020, Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced a restriction on the number of passengers allowed to travel in private vehicles. The new restriction permits 2 passengers not including the driver, and one passenger for each additional row, excluding people who live together.
type_sub_cat: Restrictions on  private vehicles in public circulation
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On August 9, Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet announced that, beginning August 11, all deliveries must be placed outside the home.

description:
Israel's Coronavirus Cabinet established a limit on the number of people in certain public spaces: one person for seven meters, or in accordance to gathering guidelines. This policy excludes restaurants (up to 20 people inside and up to 30 people outside), restaurants in a hotel (35% of capacity), and 1 person for every 6 meters in hotel swimming pools. Businesses must post signs with these restrictions to inform guests. UPDATE: On the 14th of August, 2020. The government of Israel has added the regulation: Confined Spaces:
Up to 80 square meters – Gatherings of up to 10 people are permitted
Over 80 square meters – Gatherings of up to 20 people are permitted.

description: On August 16 Israel expanded the definition of "people living together" for social distancing and gathering size purposes to now include the companion of a person with a disability. Furthermore, when ordering delivery, a person with a disability may request to bring the delivery into the house.

description: On the 18th of November, 2020. The government of Israel has allowed zoos to reopen.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
